title: Relates to voluntary discontinuances when responsive pleadings are not required
summary: Extends the time period in which a voluntary discontinuance of a civil action may be obtained without the need for a court order or stipulation of settlement; gives flexibility to parties who may want to settle claims early in the litigation process or before the lawsuit actually begins.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S2535

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the civil practice law and rules, in relation to voluntary
discontinuances

This is one of a series of measures being introduced at the request of
the Chief Administrative Judge on the recommendation of his Advisory
Committee on Civil Practice.

This measure would amend CPLR 3217(a)(1) to extend the time period in
which a voluntary discontinuance of a civil action may be obtained
without need for a court order or stipulation of settlement. As so
amended, the statute would give maximum flexibility to parties who
may want to settle claims very early in the litigation process, or
even before a lawsuit actually is begun.

Under present law, a party who alleges a cause of action in a
complaint, counterclaim, cross-claim or petition may unilaterally
discontinue it without court order or stipulation only by giving
notice thereof "at any time before a responsive pleading is served or
within twenty days after service of the pleading asserting the claim,
whichever is earlier" (emphasis added). This provides the claimant
with a maximum period of twenty days, which amounts to a very short
window of opportunity within which to discontinue one's claim without
need for court intervention or permission of one's adversary. Indeed,
our Advisory Committee believes that it is too short and that it
unnecessarily hamstrings a claimant's choices early in litigation.
Accordingly, our Committee recommends this measure, which would give
the claimant the period between service upon adversaries of the
papers commencing his or her lawsuit and service of a responsive
pleading within which to unilaterally discontinue a claim. This
change will eliminate the arbitrary twenty day cut-off without
prejudice to any other parties' rights.(1)

This measure will harmonize the CPLR with the Federal Rules of Civil
Procedure, which permit a party to discontinue a claim any time
before an answer thereto is due. See Federal Rules of Civil Procedure
41(a). Moreover, it will restore in New York the same measure of
flexibility enjoyed by practitioners in New York under the former
Rules of Civil Procedure.

This measure, which would have no fiscal impact upon the State,
would take effect on the first of January next succeeding the
date on which it shall have become a law.

PRIOR LEGISLATIVE HISTORY:
None.

EFFECTIVE DATE:

This act shall take effect on the first of January next succeeding
the date on which it shall have become a law.

FOOTNOTE:
(1) Recognizing that there are circumstances where no responsive pleading
may be required (i.e. under CPLR 3011, no responsive pleading is
required where a cross-claim is made but it is unaccompanied by any
demand for an answer), this measure preserves a twenty day rule to
prevent the situation where claimant's opportunity to unilaterally
discontinue would be without any time limitation whatsoever.
